title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. The Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents to be used for voting purposes. The Attorney General can take legal action for disparities in voting opportunities. The Voting Rights Act is amended to address disparities in in-person voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe compared to non-members. Injunctive relief may include increasing polling place availability, with jurisdiction in district courts and appeals to the Supreme Court. Such disparities are presumed to result in voting rights denial or abridgement. The Voting Rights Act is amended to address disparities in in-person voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe compared to non-members. An aggrieved person may bring an action to address such disparities, with provisions for injunctive relief and jurisdiction in district courts. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Protections Relating to Indian Reservations under Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 include requirements for approval before eliminating or moving polling places on reservations. Protections under the Voting Rights Act of 1965 require approval before changing voting locations on Indian reservations, including eliminating in-person voting, reducing early voting opportunities, or altering voting hours. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include the definition of 'Indian reservation' and expand protections to cover activities described in subsection (g) of section 4. Federal election oversight on Indian reservations is addressed in Section 4. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations if there is a complaint of potential voter rights violations based on race or color. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 allows the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations in response to complaints of potential voter rights violations based on race or color. This authorization may occur on an Indian reservation for elections, including a request for Federal observers. SEC. 5 amends Section 13(a) of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. It specifies the conditions for ending observer appointments. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 adds definitions related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations, as well as the definition of a member of an Indian tribe. SEC. 7 amends Section 203 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservations. SEC. 8 requires the Attorney General to make reports of Federal election observers publicly available. SEC. 9 addresses tribal voting consultation. SEC. 9 requires the Attorney General to consult annually with tribal organizations on voting issues for members of Indian tribes.
